newsitem.title: USA: GOLF-GREENS, PIN PLACEMENTS MAKE FOR MASTERS MISERY FOR MANY.
newsitem.headline: GOLF-GREENS, PIN PLACEMENTS MAKE FOR MASTERS MISERY FOR MANY.

text.p: Furiously fast greens, fiendish pin placements and brutal breezes combined to make Masters misery for many in Thursday's opening round at Augusta National Golf Club.
Birdies were scarce but double and triple bogeys were plentiful as the 86-man field for the season's first major championship struggled to survive.
"Every shot was a potential disaster. Every putt was a potential disaster," said Briton Colin Montgomerie, who managed to shoot even-par 72 to stay within range of the lead.

"It was probably the hardest front nine holes I'll ever play because of the greens and the pin placements," said Montgomerie, the European tour's leading money winner the last four years. The Briton shot 34 on the back nine to overcome his two-over 38 on the first nine.
Loren Roberts, one of the U.S. tour's best putters, shot 85. U.S. Open champion Steve Jones posted an 82. Ken Green recorded an 87.
"I was kind of shell shocked. I've never seen pins like this," said Roberts, who lost the 1994 U.S. Open crown in a playoff. "On a couples of holes, you had no chance."
Roberts, who had three sevens on his card, said: "It was the worst round in competition I ever had."
Things worked out better for Fred Couples, the 1992 Masters champion. But he was still spooked by conditions.
"The greens are like concrete. The pins were borderline suspect. If the weather stays like this, over par could win," he said.
U.S. tour veteran John Cook was one of the unfortunate early starters who played in bone-chilling temperatures.
"The greens are rock hard and the pins are on a slant. this morning it was 45 degrees (7 C.) and the wind was blowing 20 miles an hour (32 kph)," Cook said.
"Go out and look at the first hole, the green's blue," he said, kidding about the cold start to the day.
Temperatures warmed and the wind calmed down somewhat as the day wore on, but the greens got bumpier and later starters found little comfort on the testing layout.
"That's by far the toughest I've ever seen the course play without some strong wind or unusual conditions," said 1993 U.S. Open champion Lee Janzen.
Wind and dry weather ensured that the speed of Augusta's notoriously sloped greens would remain fast, leaving the players to call on divine intervention to soften them up.
"If the weather stays the same it's only going to get worse," said Montgomerie. "If Mother Nature doesn't help us out over par might well win. We need some help from above."
